references: Table 1 shows the results of global group fairness (EOD and DP-Dis on the global test datasets) on the three datasets. As FairFed is limited to only a single binary sensitive group, to make a fair comparison, we run the federated training twice for all three datasets (once for each sensitive group) and report the EOD and the average DP-Dis of these training rounds. As we can see from the results, FedAvg, q-FFL, and GIFAIR perform poorly as their objective is not group fairness. As for the state-of-the-art group fairness solutions, FairFed and FedFB, we find that GLocalFair can outperform these solutions in all three datasets, with a significant global group fairness enhancement. Specifically, GLocalFair can improve EOD of gender and age by 44%percent4444\% and 41%percent4141\%, respectively, and improve DP-Dis by 34%percent3434\% compared to FedFB in CelebA. We observe a similar fairness improvement for the Adult Income and UTK Faces datasets. By jointly considering all the fairness metrics, GLocalFair achieves an overall 21%percent2121\% improvement compared to FedFB and 18%percent1818\% compared to FairFed in the Adult Income dataset. For the UTK Faces dataset, GLocalFair achieves 37%percent3737\% and 40%percent4040\% fairness improvements compared to FedFB and FairFed, respectively.

From Table 1 and 2, we observe that the proposed GLocalFair offers competitive and stable performance in terms of maximizing the utility and mitigating discrepancy among the clients compared to other group-fairness-based methods. FedAvg achieves relatively higher model utility (e.g., the highest utility in the CelebA dataset) compared to other methods, which is expected as it is only optimized for utility and does not take fairness into account. Although the proposed GLocalFair is not optimized for client fairness, it can still outperform other group-fairness baselines (FedFB and FairFed). Specifically, as can be seen from Table 2, on the CelebA dataset, GLocalFair achieves an average performance improvement of 5%percent55\% and 7%percent77\% in discrepancy compared to FedFB and FairFed, respectively. Moreover, GLocalFair achieves 18%percent1818\% and 15%percent1515\% improvement on the Adult Income dataset and 6%percent66\% and 9.5%percent9.59.5\% on the UTK Faces dataset. These results show that GLocalFair can maintain a good level of model utility and client fairness while providing enhanced group fairness compared to other baselines.

references:
To compare the local group fairness, we measure the mean and standard deviation of EOD and DP-Dis on individual clients.
As shown in Table 2, we observe that the proposed GLocalFair is able to achieve a higher level of local group fairness compared to FairFed and FedFB with lower EOD and DP-Disparity values (in terms of both mean and standard deviation).
Most noticeably, in the CelebA dataset, GLocalFair can achieve an average EOD of 0.150.150.15 for the gender group, which is 48%percent4848\% lower than FedFB with the second lowest measured EOD.
To further visualize the distribution of local fairness measures across all clients, we compare the distribution of EOD and DP-Disparity with other group fairness methods in Figure 4. Note that for a completely fair model, the measured fairness metrics of clients should be of the same value and approach 00. We observe that the result of GLocalFair is more centered with lower variance, indicating better local group fairness. From the figure, we can observe that for gender groups in CelebA, almost 202020 out of 100100100 clients have near-zero EOD. Similarly, for DP-Dis in the CelebA dataset, most of the clients have less than a 0.20.20.2 disparity. These results demonstrate that by utilizing the proposed server-client co-design framework, GLocalFair can achieve greater local group fairness among the clients compared to other group fairness methods.

From Table 1 and 2, we observe that the proposed GLocalFair offers competitive and stable performance in terms of maximizing the utility and mitigating discrepancy among the clients compared to other group-fairness-based methods. FedAvg achieves relatively higher model utility (e.g., the highest utility in the CelebA dataset) compared to other methods, which is expected as it is only optimized for utility and does not take fairness into account. Although the proposed GLocalFair is not optimized for client fairness, it can still outperform other group-fairness baselines (FedFB and FairFed). Specifically, as can be seen from Table 2, on the CelebA dataset, GLocalFair achieves an average performance improvement of 5%percent55\% and 7%percent77\% in discrepancy compared to FedFB and FairFed, respectively. Moreover, GLocalFair achieves 18%percent1818\% and 15%percent1515\% improvement on the Adult Income dataset and 6%percent66\% and 9.5%percent9.59.5\% on the UTK Faces dataset. These results show that GLocalFair can maintain a good level of model utility and client fairness while providing enhanced group fairness compared to other baselines.

references: To assess the robustness of our method to data heterogeneity, we perform experiments under different data distributions, including both IID and non-IID scenarios. We distribute the dataset among n𝑛n clients such that the distribution of sensitive attributes (G) is non-IID and can be controlled using a heterogeneity controller α𝛼\alpha, where α→∞→𝛼\alpha\rightarrow\infty corresponds to IID distributions. To create this heterogeneity, we use a power law distribution Clauset et al. (2009). The results in Table 3 show that while data heterogeneity has a significant impact on baseline methods, our method is immune to it due to the use of a clustering algorithm that helps to mitigate variance among client updates.

S12.T4.caption: Table 4: Global and Local group fairness Evaluation for Dual-fold Fairness Strategy
S12.T4.table:
Method Global Fairness Local Fairness
EOD (↓↓\downarrow) DP-Dis Utility EOD DP-Dis DIS
Gender (↓↓\downarrow) (↑↑\uparrow) (Gender Group)
Mean(↓↓\downarrow) Std(↓↓\downarrow) Mean(↓↓\downarrow) Std(↓↓\downarrow) (↓↓\downarrow)
Local Fairness Constraint 0.15 0.16 81.6% 0.21 0.22 0.22 0.20 13.1%
Fairness-aware Clustering 0.13 0.12 77.9% 0.25 0.21 0.27 0.23 8.9%
GLocalFair 0.09 0.10 79.2% 0.17 0.17 0.21 0.17 9.5%
references: We embrace a dual-fold strategy for fairness optimization. This strategy encompasses both local and global dimensions of fairness. The first facet of our approach focuses on attaining local fairness by integrating a local fairness constraint optimization mechanism at the client level. Complementing this, the second facet of our approach addresses global fairness through a distinctive methodology that employs fairness-aware clustering-based aggregation on the server side. This server-level operation aspires to harmonize the contributions from diverse clients, ensuring that the aggregation process mitigates the amplification of any inherent disparities. To rigorously assess the efficacy of these individual fairness enhancement methods, we conducted an additional experiment using the CelebA dataset. Specifically, the experiment aims to evaluate the unique contributions of each strategy (client-level or server-level) to the overall fairness improvement. We use FedAvg on the server for aggregation when we use local fairness constraint optimization only. In Table 4, we show the results of local fairness constraint optimization and the fairness-aware clustering-based aggregation individually. As we can observe from the table, the global fairness measured on the global model is lower when we employ only the local fairness constraints on the client side, but it gets improved when fairness-aware clustering is used, showing the local fairness improvement does not fully improve the global fairness. Similarly, when the local fairness constraints are used, the local fairness is improved, but the discrepancy among the client’s performance is degraded due to the use of FedAvg on the server side. Local fairness is degraded when only the fairness-aware clustering is used on the server side, but the discrepancy among the client’s performance is improved. When we combine both the fairness strategies in GLocalFair, they complement each other and improve both local and global group fairness.

references:
At each client, we use constraint optimization on top of the learning algorithm to enforce local fairness. In each round of training, we constrain the false positive rate (FPR) and false negative rate (FNR) and use a misclassification penalty for constraint violations.
We evaluate GLocalFair with different τF​P​Rsubscript𝜏𝐹𝑃𝑅\tau_{FPR} values (i.e., 0.08, 0.10, 0.15, and 0.20) and a fixed τF​N​Rsubscript𝜏𝐹𝑁𝑅\tau_{FNR} value (i.e., 0.100.100.10) on the CelebA dataset in Table 5. We observe that it achieves the best performance when τF​P​R=0.08subscript𝜏𝐹𝑃𝑅0.08\tau_{FPR}=0.08.
Although further decreasing τF​P​Rsubscript𝜏𝐹𝑃𝑅\tau_{FPR} may seemingly increase performance, in our experiments, we find that any τF​P​Rsubscript𝜏𝐹𝑃𝑅\tau_{FPR} values smaller than 0.080.080.08 would result in a trivial model that outputs the same prediction for all data samples.
On the other hand, if we increase τF​P​Rsubscript𝜏𝐹𝑃𝑅\tau_{FPR} to be larger than 0.150.150.15, there would be almost no effect of constraint as the model will converge with an FPR value lower than the limit.
We also test a few combinations with varying τF​N​Rsubscript𝜏𝐹𝑁𝑅\tau_{FNR}.
We find that with τF​P​Rsubscript𝜏𝐹𝑃𝑅\tau_{FPR} fixed, using a smaller τF​N​Rsubscript𝜏𝐹𝑁𝑅\tau_{FNR} value can help improve model fairness. However, if we set both τF​N​Rsubscript𝜏𝐹𝑁𝑅\tau_{FNR} and τF​P​Rsubscript𝜏𝐹𝑃𝑅\tau_{FPR} to 0.080.080.08, it over-constraints the model and makes it unstable. Also, any value larger than 0.150.150.15 for τF​N​Rsubscript𝜏𝐹𝑁𝑅\tau_{FNR} has almost no effect on the model performance.

S12.T6.caption: Table 6: Global group fairness vs. model utility with different fairness level γ𝛾\gamma.
S12.T6.table:
Fairness Indicator EOD (↓↓\downarrow) DP-Dis Utility
(γ𝛾\gamma) Gender Age (↓↓\downarrow) (↑↑\uparrow)
0.2 0.41 0.43 0.36 82.5%
0.4 0.23 0.25 0.15 80.6%
0.6 0.09 0.10 0.10 79.1%
0.8 0.09 0.11 0.10 78.9%
references:
In the design of GLocalFair, we use γ𝛾\gamma to control the balance between fairness and utility of the global model.
A larger γ𝛾\gamma value would result in a fairer model with lower utility.
We evaluate GLocalFair with different γ𝛾\gamma values on the CelebA dataset and summarize the results in Table 6.We can observe that as γ𝛾\gamma increases, the utility of the model decreases while the fairness performance saturates at γ=0.6𝛾0.6\gamma=0.6. Therefore, we set γ=0.6𝛾0.6\gamma=0.6 in our major experiments, which ensures the model’s fairness while still maintaining a good level of utility.

S12.T7.table:
τF​P​Rsubscript𝜏𝐹𝑃𝑅\tau_{FPR} τF​N​Rsubscript𝜏𝐹𝑁𝑅\tau_{FNR} Utility (↑↑\uparrow) Precision Recall
0.06 - 80.9% 0.95 0.75
0.08 - 78.9% 0.94 0.75
- 0.06 78.6% 0.87 0.90
- 0.08 80.5% 0.87 0.88
references:
The developed GLocalFair offers customizable fairness configurations on the client side, aiming to cater to diverse fairness requirements.
To evaluate this feature, we intentionally alternate between fixing the FPR and FNR while relaxing the other fairness constraint, mirroring real-world scenarios where a preference for lower FPR or FNR varies. As shown in Table 7,
across all scenarios, we observe consistently high utility scores.
constraining FPR results in high precision values, around 0.95, indicating accurate positive predictions. However, this often leads to a lower recall due to the unconstrained FNR, resulting in a higher number of false negatives.
Conversely, when FNR is constrained, recall is notably high, signifying comprehensive positive predictions. Nevertheless, in these instances, precision tends to be lower due to the unconstrained FPR, which results in a higher number of false positives. These findings underscore the importance and effectiveness of customizable fairness configurations in GLocalFair, as they enable the adaptation of model behavior to varying fairness requirements and real-world scenarios.
